title: Is there a signal of sea-level rise in Chesapeake Bay salinity?
description: This paper detects the influence of sea level rise on salinity in an estuary. This finding is backed up with results from a 3-D hydrodynamic model, a tool now used routinely to project future salinity change in estuaries.
authors: Hilton, T.W., Najjar, R.G., Zhong, L. and Li, M.

title: Sea-level rise and other influences on decadal-scale variations of salinity in a coastal plain estuary
description: This paper uses observations and models to show that sea level rise leads to salinity increases in Delaware Bay. A new and serious impact of climate change on estuaries.
authors: Ross, A.C., Najjar, R.G., Li, M., Mann, M.E., Ford, S.E. and Katz, B.

title: A metamodel-based analysis of the sensitivity and uncertainty of the response of Chesapeake Bay salinity and circulation to projected climate change
description: This paper makes predictions about how changes in sea level, streamflow, and open-ocean tides may influence salinity and stratification in the Chesapeake Bay by the middle of the 21st century.
authors: Ross, A.C., Najjar, R.G. and Li, M.

title: Rising seas, changing salt lines, and drinking water salinization
description: This paper reviews the literature to evaluate how climate change is shifting the location of global ‘salt lines,’ the zone where coastal fresh water meets the ocean, and implications for drinking water management.

title: Planning for Drinking Water Salinization in the US Atlantic and Gulf Coast Regions
description: This paper examines 264 climate plans and 7 state water plans from the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States to examine how municipalities, regions, and states are preparing for drinking water salinization.

title: The anthropogenic salt cycle
description: This paper develops a national biogeochemical salt budget for the continental U.S. and shows that riverine salt fluxes are increasing due to a variety of increasing anthropogenic salt sources
authors: Kaushal, S.S., Likens, G.E., Mayer, P.M., Shatkay, R.R., Shelton, S.A., Grant, S.B., Utz, R.M., Yaculak, A.M., Maas, C.M., Reimer, J.E. and Bhide, S.V.

title: Freshwater salinization syndrome on a continental scale
description: This paper quantifies increasing trends in different salt ions across the continental U.S., and derives empirical relationships between specific conductance and pH trends in over 200 USGS sites.
authors: Kaushal, S.S., Likens, G.E., Pace, M.L., Utz, R.M., Haq, S., Gorman, J. and Grese, M.

title: Increased river alkalinization in the Eastern US
description: This paper documents increasing river alkalinization in 2/3 of the major rivers draining the Eastern U.S., and increasing calcium trends, caused by human-accelerated weathering.
authors: Kaushal, S.S., Likens, G.E., Utz, R.M., Pace, M.L., Grese, M. and Yepsen, M.
